    • Prerequisites
    • 1. Ingest a Dataset
      • Object Relational Model (ORM)
      • a) Registering Datasets
        • Dataset.Tabular

        • Dataset.Tabular
        • Dataset.Sequence
        • Dataset.Image
    • 2. Selecting Features and Labels.
      • a) Select the Label column(s).
        • ORM
        • Deriving Labels
        • Reading Labels
      • b) Select the Feature column(s).
        • ORM
        • Specifying Features
        • Reading Features
    • 3. Slicing samples.
      • a) Define sliding time series Windows.
        • ORM
        • Specifying Windows
        • Reading Windows
      • b) Slice samples with a Splitset.
        • Stratification
        • Splitting Strategies
        • Reading Splitsets
      • c) fold_count triggers cross-validation.
        • ORM
        • Fold objects
        • Specifying Folds
        • Reading Folds
    • 4. Preprocessing - Interpolation.
      • ORM
      • a) Interpolate Labels with LabelInterpolater.
      • b) Interpolate Features with Interpolaterset.
    • 5. Preprocessing - Encoding.
      • Encoding
      • a) Encode labels with LabelCoder.
        • Creating a LabelCoder
      • b) Encode Features sequentially with FeatureCoders.
        • Filtering feature columns
    • 6. Preprocessing - Reshaping.
      • ORM
      • Reshaping by Index
      • Reshaping Explicitly
      • Multiplicative Reshaping
    • 7. Defining Architectures & Hyperparameters.
      • a) Define an Algorithm
        • Model Definition
        • Group the functions together in an Algorithm!
      • b) Combinations of hyperparameters with Hyperparamset.
        • Hyperparameter Selection Strategies.
        • Hyperparamcombo objects.
    • 8. Queue of training Jobs.
      • a) Job objects.
      • b) Executing Jobs.
        • i) queue.run_jobs()
        • ii) DEPRECATED - queue.run_jobs(in_background=True).
      • c) Predictors are the trained models.
        • Fetching the trained model.
        • Fetching the hyperparameters.
      • d) Predictions are the output of a Predictor.
        • Fetching metrics.
    • 9. Metrics & Visualization

  • PyTorch: Tabular Regression

PyTorch: Tabular Regression

Predicting Exoplanet Surface Temperature Using Kepler Satellite Sensor Data.

Example Data

Reference Example Datasets for more information.

This dataset is comprised of:

  • Features = characteristics of the planet in the context of its solar system.

  • Label = the temperature of the planet.

[2]:

from aiqc import datum
from aiqc.orm import Dataset

[3]:

df = datum.to_pandas('exoplanets.parquet')
shared_dataset = Dataset.Tabular.from_pandas(df)
df.head()

[3]:
TypeFlag PlanetaryMassJpt PeriodDays SurfaceTempK DistFromSunParsec HostStarMassSlrMass HostStarRadiusSlrRad HostStarMetallicity HostStarTempK
5 0 0.2500 19.224180 707.2 650.00 1.070 1.0200 0.12 5777.0

7 0 0.0220 1.592851 1601.5 650.00 1.070 1.0200 0.12 5777.0
15 0 1.2400 2.705782 2190.0 200.00 1.630 2.1800 0.12 6490.0
16 0 0.0195 1.580404 604.0 14.55 0.176 0.2213 0.10 3250.0

Pipeline

Reference High-Level API Docs for more information.

[4]:

from aiqc.mlops import Pipeline, Input, Target, Stratifier
from sklearn.preprocessing import StandardScaler, RobustScaler, OneHotEncoder

[5]:

pipeline = Pipeline(
    Input(
        dataset  = shared_dataset,
        encoders = [
            Input.Encoder(
                RobustScaler(),
                dtypes = ['float64']
            ),
            Input.Encoder(
                OneHotEncoder(),
                dtypes = ['int64']
            )
        ]
    ),

    Target(
        dataset = shared_dataset
        , column  = 'SurfaceTempK'
        , encoder = Target.Encoder(StandardScaler())
    ),

    Stratifier(
        size_test         = 0.12
        , size_validation = 0.22
        , fold_count      = None
        , bin_count       = 4
    )
)


└── Info - System overriding user input to set `sklearn_preprocess.copy=False`.
        This saves memory when concatenating the output of many encoders.


└── Info - System overriding user input to set `sklearn_preprocess.copy=False`.
        This saves memory when concatenating the output of many encoders.


└── Info - System overriding user input to set `sklearn_preprocess.sparse=False`.
        This would have generated 'scipy.sparse.csr.csr_matrix', causing Keras training to fail.

Modeling

Reference High-Level API Docs for more information.

[6]:

from aiqc.mlops import Experiment, Architecture, Trainer
import torch.nn as nn
from torch import optim
import torchmetrics as tm
from aiqc.utils.pytorch import fit

[20]:

def fn_build(features_shape, label_shape, **hp):
    # Just giving hyperparameter a shorter reference.
    nc = hp['neuron_count']

    model = nn.Sequential(
        nn.Linear(features_shape[-1], nc)
        , nn.BatchNorm1d(nc,nc)
        , nn.ReLU()
        , nn.Dropout(p=0.4)

        , nn.Linear(nc, nc)
        , nn.BatchNorm1d(nc,nc)
        , nn.ReLU()
        , nn.Dropout(p=0.4)

        , nn.Linear(nc, label_shape[-1])
    )
    return model

[21]:

def fn_train(
    model, loser, optimizer,
    train_features, train_label,
    eval_features, eval_label,
    **hp
):
    model = fit(
        model, loser, optimizer,
        train_features, train_label,
        eval_features, eval_label
        , epochs     = 30
        , batch_size = 5
        , metrics    = [tm.MeanSquaredError(), tm.R2Score()]
    )
    return model

Optional, will be automatically selected based on analysis_type if left as None.

[22]:

def fn_lose(**hp):
    if (hp['loss_type'] == 'mae'):
        loser = nn.L1Loss()#mean absolute error.
    elif (hp['loss_type'] == 'mse'):
        loser = nn.MSELoss()
    return loser

[23]:

hyperparameters = dict(
    neuron_count=[22,24], loss_type=["mae","mse"]
)

[24]:

experiment = Experiment(
    Architecture(
        library           = "pytorch"
        , analysis_type   = "regression"
        , fn_build        = fn_build
        , fn_train        = fn_train
        , hyperparameters = hyperparameters
    ),

    Trainer(pipeline=pipeline, repeat_count=1)
)

[25]:

experiment.run_jobs()

🔮 Training Models 🔮: 100%|██████████████████████████████████████████| 4/4 [00:13<00:00,  3.36s/it]
